item.title: A Beginner's Guide to the Sun \& Moon through Lost Thunder Format
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • 1: An Introduction to SUM-LOT
  • 2: Important Cards
    • Supporters
    • Items
    • Stadiums
    • Pokemon
  • 3: An Overview of the Metagame
  • 4: Decklists

An Introduction to SUM-LOT

The Sun and Moon era of the Pokemon TCG is looked back on extremely fondly by competitively players, and rightly so. After the dominance of big-basic strategies in the Black and White era, and them continuing into XY due to the lackluster Mega Evolution mechanic, it was exciting to see the evolving Pokemon GX take over the reigns. With the introduction of the first few Sun and Moon sets, many of the less than desirable attributes of the XY era persisted: an over reliance on “turbo” item cards, basic pokemon dominating the format, and supporters that were extremely powerful with no negative impact on deck consistency. Almost every deck ran 4 Trainers’ mail, VS Seeker and Puzzle of Time, with hopes of setting up faster than their opponent. If this wasn’t enough, the format included Professor Sycamore for draw support, N for late game disruption and even more early draw support, and Lysandre for unconditional gusting, all with unparalleled ease of access with VS seeker.

item.title: Some Thoughts on Video Games I've Played in 2025
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Monster Hunter Wilds
  • Baldur’s Gate III
  • Fantasy Life i: The Girl who Steals Time
  • Turnip Boy Robs a Bank
  • Mario Kart World
  • Donkey Kong Bananza
  • Hollow Knight: Silksong
  • Pokemon Legends Z-A
  • Super Mario RPG
  • Monster Sanctuary
  • Persona 4 Golden
  • Kirby Air Riders

Monster Hunter Wilds

First Played: 2/28/2025
Play Time so Far: 24 hours
Overall Review Score: 4/7

This section may turn into a rant, but it’s whatever. I was so incredibly excited for this game. I first played Monster Hunter Tri on the Wii with my friend in 3rd grade, and was immediately hooked. I’ve played 200 hours of MH3U, at least 700 hours of MH4U, 600 hours of MHG+MHGU, and like 400 hours of MHRise. I adore Monster Hunter Stories and Stories 2, and even went back and bought a PSP to bang my head against a wall in Freedom Unite. It’s safe to say I’m a pretty big fan of the Monster Hunter series. Despite this, you might notice that I’ve played almost all Monster Hunter releases except for Monster Hunter World and Iceborne. This is because I am a filthy casual who only owned a 3DS and a Switch at the time, and didn’t think it was worth it to buy a nice PC or console to play World. (I was also like 17 and didn’t have much disposable income to drop on such things)
